node.title: 'He wasn't only my son, he was my mate': Father mourns son who died in boat tragedy
node.description: One of the men killed in the Far North fishing boat tragedy was worried about the weather forecast before he went on the trip, his devastated father says.

node.title: Heavy rain with flooding potential forecast for Bay of Plenty, Gisborne
node.description: As Aucklanders clean up from the wild weather, parts of Bay of Plenty and Gisborne may be next in the firing line. Audio

node.title: Chicago dance ensemble gives Ukrainian children a distraction from war
node.description: A Chicago dance group is helping Ukraine's youngest victims by temporarily taking their minds off the war.

node.title: Egypt displays treasures of recently discovered ancient tombs
node.description: The five tombs date back to the Old Kingdom — a period spanning roughly from 2700 BC to 2200 BC.

node.title: Businesses look forward to operations after Covid-19 mandates
node.description: Businesses are willing to open their doors to unvaccinated customers as the government mulls doing away with Covid-19 mandates and vaccine passes. Audio

node.title: NZ small businesses 'not digitally savvy' like Asia-Pacific peers - survey
node.description: Small businesses are lagging behind the rest of the region globally when it comes to growth, social media, online sales and new methods of payment.

node.title: Where are the promised inquiries into the Parliament protest?
node.description: In the aftermath of the three-week occupation of Parliament, where are the promised inquiries into what happened, and what could be done to prevent it happening again?

node.title: Councillors defy mayor's climate action opposition
node.description: Thames Coromandel district councillors have defied their mayor's opposition to signing the Climate Leaders Declaration.

node.title: 96-year-old Holocaust survivor killed by shelling in Ukraine
node.description: Romanchenko survived the concentration camps at Buchenwald, Dora-Mittelbau, Peenemünde and Bergen-Belson during World War II.

node.title: Timing stings for commercial sector as NZTA reviews fees
node.description: Waka Kotahi says private motorists have been subsidising the commercial sector for too long and it plans to even the playing field by upping operators' fees at the end of next year.

node.title: SFO files corruption charges against former Auckland DHB employee
node.description: The Serious Fraud Office has filed charges against two people accused of corruption in the procurement and supply of medical equipment.

node.title: 'Really scary': Auckland homes face major clean up after floods
node.description: There are likely weeks of clean up ahead for some homes in Auckland and Northland after the violent storm that hit the region yesterday morning.

node.title: Blinken declares Myanmar's repression of Muslim Rohingya genocide
node.description: It is the eighth time since the Holocaust that the U.S. has made a genocide declaration.

node.title: Ruby Tui: Plotting the Black Ferns return to the top
node.description: The Chiefs Manawa are the inaugural Super Rugby Aupiki champions, but what needs to happen next to put the Black Ferns back on top of the world?

node.title: Government wants companies to disclose climate-change risks
node.description: New SEC proposal requires companies to spell out bottom-line impacts of everything from floods to rising fuel costs.

node.title: Supply lines suffering further delays due to Omicron outbreak
node.description: Ports of Auckland has had many staff sick or isolating and more ships are diverting to Northport, near Whangārei, the Custom Brokers and Freight Forwarders Federation says.

node.title: 'We need to investigate all possibilities' - Police dive squad
node.description: The police dive squad will this morning join the operation to locate the final missing person from the tragic North Cape boating incident on Sunday. Audio

node.title: Watch: NZ pledges another $5m to support Ukraine and give military aid
node.description: The New Zealand Government has agreed to send non-lethal military equipment to Ukraine, such as military body armour, helmets and vests.

node.title: Nuclear disaster fears raise the stakes in Ukraine invasion
node.description: For more than three decades, very little has disturbed the Chernobyl exclusion zone, the site of the worst nuclear accident in human history - until Russia invaded Ukraine.

node.title: Called out by Zelenskyy, Nestle defends its Russia business
node.description: In a speech streamed to protesters in Switzerland, Ukraine's president singles out Swiss food company for refusing to exit.

node.title: "West Side Story" star says she wasn't invited to the Oscars
node.description: "I'm disappointed too," Zegler said. "But that's okay. So proud of our movie."

node.title: Girl who sang "Let It Go" in Ukraine bomb shelter performs for thousands
node.description: Thousands of people waved lights in the darkened stadium as 7-year-old Amellia Anisovych sang Ukraine's anthem.

node.title: Armstrong's puts brakes on share float
node.description: One of the country's biggest car dealers, Armstrong's, has put plans for a share float on hold because of financial market uncertainty.

node.title: DHB boss expects Canterbury Covid-19 cases to peak this week
node.description: In the South Island, 462 Canterbury District Health Board staff members are away because of Covid-19.

node.title: Wellington Water under the pump over poor condition of network assets
node.description: While Wellington Water is falling short in the capital city, other councils in the region say they are managing the water company just fine because they are spending more.

node.title: Mandates, vaccine passes and traffic light system up for review today
node.description: Covid-19 restrictions look set to be relaxed in the coming weeks as the Omicron outbreak plateaus and the border begins to reopen.

node.title: Fonterra to 'exit its business' in Russia following the invasion of Ukraine
node.description: Fonterra is closing its Moscow office, and has withdrawn from its joint venture with Unifood in Russia, established more than three years ago.

node.title: Hamish Kerr makes history with medal at World Indoor Champs
node.description: Hamish Kerr has finished third at the World Indoor Athletics championship in Serbia, becoming the first New Zealander to win a global high jump medal.

node.title: Meta involved in "extremist activities," Russian court rules
node.description: The ruling applies to Facebook and Instagram, but spares WhatsApp, according to Russian news source Novaya Gazette.

node.title: The secrets to saving money at the pump by "hyper-miling" on the road
node.description: Wayne Gerdis said his slow and steady approach to driving has been getting him well over 80 miles per gallon, saving him about $2,500 a year.
